DRZ400/DRZ400sm Countershaft fix

While I was changing my wheels the other day I thought I’d change my countershaft sprocket as well. I put my socket wrench on it, gave it a slight pull, and the nut popped right off, taking the countershaft’s threads right along with it.

At this point the only “real” fix is to pull the engine, split the cases, and replace the countershaft, which is about $112 from ronayers.com

Here’s the how to fix it for about $2.

before:

1) First I got a new sprocket, and ground the collar off. This means my chain alignment isn’t perfect, but it did give me a few more mm or countershaft to work with which was desperately needed.
2) put the sprocket on, and hit the sprocket/shaft with some spraypaint. this gives you a line on the sprocket where you’ll cut.
3) using a demel cut around the shaft, the depth of the teeth is perfect.
4) put on sprocket and install “e” clip. ta da, you just saved yourself A LOT OF MONEY.

Option B. if you don’t have enough shaft to cut, you can weld the sprocket on. This will get you until you need to rebuild the engine. Note that if you sell the bike in this condition without telling the buyer, you’re going to hell….

Thanks Damm Dummy Racing for the wrenchin help, and Jon Doublex for the idea.

After:

Edit/update: IT HAPPENED AGAIN, this time sending yours truly to the hospital. The problem was aftermarket sprockets don’t have the rubber bushing built in, and the vibes cause the countershaft to snap. So use the stock rubberized cs sprocket.

As far as the fix, on the first bike it’s worked/laste 1.5 years with no problems. the e clip was replaced with a retainer clip, and I put a little permatex hightemp silicone around the clip as well to help with vibes. I’ve done the same fix with the second bike. 3rd bike still has it’s nut, I’m running the stock rubberized cs sprocket and have added some permatex around the nut.
